chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This guide provides information on how to configure DNSSEC using BIND9. Readers are assumed to have basic knowledge of the Domain Name System (DNS) and related network infrastructure. In-depth knowledge of DNS or DNSSEC, and public key cryptography are not required. This guide is intended for system administrators, engineers, and consultants who are new to DNSSEC, or those who understand the technology but need configuration and deployment examples.

section.title: What is DNSSEC?
section.para: The Domain Name System (DNS), originally described in RFC1034 and RFC1035, was designed in a day and age when the Internet was a friendly and trusting place. The protocol provides no mechanism to guard against malicious or forged answers. DNS Security Extensions (DNSSEC) (RFC4033, RFC4034 and RFC4035) was proposed to address this need, by adding digital signatures into DNS data, so each DNS response can be verified for authenticity. In the ideal world when DNSSEC is completely rolled out, every single DNS answer can be validated and trusted.

DNSSEC adds resource records and message header bits, this additional information ca be used by other DNS reoslvers to verify that the requested data matches what the zone administrator put in the zone, and has not been altered in transit. DNSSEC does not provide a secure tunnel; it doesn’t encrypt or hide DNS data. It was designed with backwards compatibility in mind. The original standard DNS protocol continues to work the same.

There are two major components to DNSSEC:
Recursive Server: People use recursive servers to lookup external domain names such www.example.com. Operators of recursive servers need to enable DNSSEC validation. With validation enabled, recursive servers will carry out additional tasks on each DNS response it receives to ensure its authenticity.
>Authoritative Server: People who own domain names and operate their own name servers, need to “sign” DNS zone data on authoritative servers, this entails creating additional resource records, and publish them to parent domains where necessary. With DNSSEC enabled, authoritative servers will respond with additional DNS data, such as digital signatures and keys, in addition to the standard answers.
In this guide, we will dive into details of how DNSSEC works, how to configure a validating resolver, how to sign DNS zone data, and other operational tasks.
